WASHINGTON — Leaders of the House commerce committee said Thursday they will ask Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify before the panel amid revelations that Cambridge Analytica — a data analysis firm that worked for Donald Trump's presidential campaign — stole sensitive information from tens of millions of Facebook users.

Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Greg Walden, R-Ore., and senior Democrat Frank Pallone of New Jersey, said they plan to send a formal letter to Zuckerberg soon to arrange a specific date and time for him to appear "in the near future."
"The latest revelations regarding Facebook’s use and security of user data raises many serious consumer protection concerns," Walden and Pallone said in a joint statement.
Facebook has faced growing scrutiny since disclosing last week that it knew Cambridge Analytica had taken users' personal information without their consent.
The company obtained the information from a psychology researcher who legitimately gleaned details on users' likes and habits from a 2013 personality quiz.
CLOSE Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg posted a message Wednesday admitting mistakes in a privacy scandal involving a data mining firm with Trump connections.
Facebook didn't verify Cambridge Analytica's claims that it had deleted the information, and didn't notify users that the firm had taken their data.
"After committee staff received a briefing (Wednesday) from Facebook officials, we felt that many questions were left unanswered."
Walden and Pallone noted that "Mr. Zuckerberg has stated that he would be willing to testify if he is the right person."
"We believe, as CEO of Facebook, he is the right witness to provide answers to the American people," the lawmakers said.
The House will be in recess for the next two weeks, so the earliest that Zuckerberg would be asked to testify is April.
Zuckerberg told reporters Wednesday that he would be willing to testify before Congress.
